pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Enzymes</button> are biological catalysts that speed up chemical reactions by reducing the amount of energy needed to make the reactions proceed. In fact, most biological reactions do not occur at appreciable rates in the absence of enzymes. In this investigation, you will use the enzyme catalase, which catalyzes the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide (H<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>), a toxic by-product of cellular metabolism. You will measure and evaluate the effects of enzyme concentration and temperature on the reaction rate.

text: Explain how <button class='glossary-text'>enzymes</button> bind to their <button class='glossary-text'>substrate</button> and identify factors that influence the rate of enzyme-catalyzed reactions.
Perform an experiment to assess the impact of enzyme concentration on the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide as a result of the enzymatic activity of catalase.
Perform an experiment to assess the impact of temperature on the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide as a result of the enzymatic activity of catalase.
Graph and analyze data collected.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Enzymes</button> speed up reactions and play a crucial role in many industries. Some of the more well-known enzymes are used in the production of biofuels, beer and wine, and bread making. However, enzymes are also used in clarifying fruit juices and to make cleaning detergents work more efficiently, at a lower temperature and with less water.

Since the 1960s, the addition of enzymes into cleaning products has gained in popularity. Most biological detergents contain at least two different enzymes, but some contain up to eight. Biological detergents usually contain enzymes, surfactants, and builders. The most popular group of enzymes used in detergents are hydrolases (proteases, amylases, lipases, and mannanases). Hydrolases work by removing stains, including food, grass, blood, animal and vegetable fat, and dirt. Many of the enzymes can hydrolyze and break the peptide bonds of stains and dirt. It is because of enzymes that different types of fabrics can all be put into one load of laundry, washed in cold water, and still come out clean.

pageData.desc: The door of a frontloading washing machine through which the movement of soapy water and clothes is visible.
pageData.altText: The door of a frontloading washing machine through which the movement of soapy water and clothes is visible.

pageData.text: For a chemical reaction to occur, reactants must collide with sufficient force to break their chemical bonds, allowing new bonds to be formed between the products. All chemical reactions in living organisms would be too slow to sustain life without specialized substances called . Enzymes act as catalysts to speed up chemical reactions by lowering the of a reaction (Figure 1). Activation energy is the minimum amount of energy required to start a chemical reaction.Activation energy is present when kinetic energy drives reactants to a level where their random collisions are strong enough to ensure the interaction in such a way that the reactants’ bonds break and are rearranged into products. Enzymes work by stabilizing the transition state of the , allowing it to move to the product state. In other words, the enzyme creates an environment that allows the reaction to proceed. Enzymes and their cognate substrates fit together. The “lock-and-key” model suggests that the active site of an enzyme precisely fits a specific substrate (Figure 2a). The induced fit model states that the active site of an enzyme undergoes a when binding to a substrate, which improves the fit (Figure 2b). On every enzyme, there is a binding, or active site, shaped to fit a specific substrate. This allows enzymes to work with high efficiency and specificity. Like all catalysts, the enzyme is not consumed in the reaction and can be used repeatedly.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Two graphs of energy versus the progress of the reaction. Graph A: the reaction occurs without an enzyme. The reaction starts with 2 reactants with medium energy and proceeds to a high energy level before concluding to a single product with low energy. The difference between the starting reaction energy and the highest reaction energy is labeled, activation energy required, and shows a long vertical arrow. Graph B: the reaction occurs with an enzyme. The reaction starts with 2 reactants with medium energy and proceeds to a slightly higher energy level before concluding to a single product with low energy. The difference between the starting reaction energy and the highest reaction energy is labeled, less activation energy required, and shows a small vertical arrow.

Figure 2: Two diagrams of models of enzyme action. A) Lock and key model.  An enzyme has an active site with a shape perfectly complementary to the shapes of 2 substrate molecules, forming a substrate complex as all 3 molecules are joined together. B) Induced-fit model. An enzyme has an active site with a shape that is not perfectly complementary to the shape of 2 substrates. The active site is labeled, the active site changes to fit. The resulting substrate complex looks identical to the substrate complex of the lock-and-key model.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the shape of an enzyme’s active site according to the lock-and-key model of enzyme action?

options.text: It is specific to its cognate substrates.
It changes to fit whatever substrates are in the immediate area.
It is generic to fit multiple types of substrates.
It is flat until altered by the surrounding pH.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: On every enzyme, there is an active site shaped to fit a a specific substrate.

pageData.question: How do enzymes lower the activation energy of a chemical reaction?

options.text: They stabilize the transition state of the substrate as it becomes a product.
They slow the movement of electrons around the atoms in the substrate.
They produce ions to alter the pH of the substrate’s environment.
They bind to substrates to give them a polar molecular charge.
They reduce the temperature of the substrate’s environment.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Enzymes work by stabilizing the transition state of the substrate, allowing it to move to the product state.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Enzymes act as catalysts to speed up chemical reactions by lowering the activation energy of a reaction. Activation energy is present when kinetic energy drives reactants to a level where their random collisions are strong enough to ensure the interaction in such a way that the reactants’ bonds break and are rearranged into products. Enzyme creates an environment that allows the reaction to proceed. It does this by stabilizing the transition state of the reactant(s), also called the substrate, allowing it to move to the product state. Enzymes and their cognate substrates fit together. The “lock-and-key” model suggests that the active site of an enzyme precisely fits a specific substrate (Figure 2a). The induced fit model states that the active site of an enzyme undergoes a conformational change when binding to a substrate, which improves the fit (Figure 2b).

img.alt: Figure 21: Two diagrams of models of enzyme action. A) Lock and key model.  An enzyme has an active site with a shape perfectly complementary to the shapes of 2 substrate molecules, forming a substrate complex as all 3 molecules are joined together. B) Induced-fit model. An enzyme has an active site with a shape that is not perfectly complementary to the shape of 2 substrates. The active site is labeled, the active site changes to fit. The resulting substrate complex looks identical to the substrate complex of the lock-and-key model.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Enzymes act as catalysts to speed up chemical reactions by lowering the activation energy of a reaction. Activation energy is present when kinetic energy drives reactants to a level where their random collisions are strong enough to ensure the interaction in such a way that the reactants’ bonds break and are rearranged into products. Enzyme creates an environment that allows the reaction to proceed. It does this by stabilizing the transition state of the reactant(s), also called the substrate, allowing it to move to the product state. Enzymes and their cognate substrates fit together. The “lock-and-key” model suggests that the active site of an enzyme precisely fits a specific substrate (Figure 2a). The induced fit model states that the active site of an enzyme undergoes a conformational change when binding to a substrate, which improves the fit (Figure 2b).

img.alt: Figure 2: Two diagrams of models of enzyme action. A) Lock and key model.  An enzyme has an active site with a shape perfectly complementary to the shapes of 2 substrate molecules, forming a substrate complex as all 3 molecules are joined together. B) Induced-fit model. An enzyme has an active site with a shape that is not perfectly complementary to the shape of 2 substrates. The active site is labeled, the active site changes to fit. The resulting substrate complex looks identical to the substrate complex of the lock-and-key model.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Enzymes</button> in living organisms operate best within a narrow range of environmental conditions (e.g., temperature, concentration, pH, etc.). For example, the human digestive system utilizes several enzymes to break down food. Different enzymes operate in different parts of the digestive tract. Some parts of the digestive tract are acidic (pH less than 7), whereas others are alkaline or basic (pH greater than 7). The stomach contains acidic gastric juices that aid digestion. Enzymes active in the stomach function best in that acidic environment. When food exits the stomach it enters the small intestine, which provides a more alkaline environment so the acidic food coming from the stomach can be neutralized. Enzymes active in the small intestine function best in a weakly alkaline environment. When pH values are outside the optimum range for digestive enzymes, <button class='glossary-text'>denaturing</button> of the molecule or alteration of the active site shape can occur so that the enzyme cannot accept the <button class='glossary-text'>substrate</button>. Enzymes active in the stomach are inactive in the small intestine and vice versa.

The protein catalase is a common enzyme found in animals as well as many plants and even microorganisms. Catalase decomposes hydrogen peroxide, a toxic by-product of cellular metabolism, before it is able to damage the cell. The reaction produces water and oxygen gas (O<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>), which are nontoxic. Applying hydrogen peroxide to a wound is an example of this reaction:
2 H<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub> → 2 H<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>O + O<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>
The gas in the bubbles of the white foam produced is oxygen gas generated from the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide in the presence of catalase in human tissues.

In this investigation, you will use catalase produced by yeast. A filter paper disk soaked in catalase will be placed in a medicine cup, and the hydrogen peroxide (H<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>) will decompose, forming oxygen gas bubbles on the disk that will lift it to the surface. In Activity 1, you will investigate the following question: How does the concentration of the enzyme catalase affect the decomposition rate of the substrate hydrogen peroxide? In Activity 2, you will determine how the temperature of catalase affects the decomposition rate of the substrate, and find the optimum temperature at which catalase is most active.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Catalase decomposes hydrogen peroxide, a toxic by-product of cellular metabolism, before it can damage the cell. The reaction produces water and oxygen gas (O2), which are nontoxic.

pageData.question: Catalase breaks down hydrogen peroxide into which of the following products?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Catalase decomposes hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen gas, which are nontoxic.

The protein catalase is a common enzyme found in animals as well as many plants and even microorganisms. Catalase decomposes hydrogen peroxide, a toxic by-product of cellular metabolism, before it can damage the cell. The reaction produces water and oxygen gas (O2), which are nontoxic. In this investigation, you will use catalase produced by yeast. In this investigation, you will explore how enzyme concentration and environmental temperature affect the reaction rate of catalase.2 H2O2 → 2 H2O + O2

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for Activity 1 of this investigation. Before starting any activities, prepare the filter paper disks, cover your work surface, create a 100% catalase solution, and label your pipets. In Activity 1, create a 1.5% hydrogen peroxide solution. Then, label test tubes with catalase concentrations and create catalase dilutions in the test tubes. Next, soak a disk in a catalase dilution and add the disk to the hydrogen peroxide solution. Record the time for the disk to float. Repeat the disk-floating process for a total of 2 trials for each catalase concentration. Then, calculate the average float time for each reaction, determine the distance traveled by floating disks, calculate the rate of each reaction, and graph rate versus percent concentration of enzyme.
pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for Activity 1 of this investigation. Before starting any activities, prepare the filter paper disks, cover your work surface, create a 100% catalase solution, and label your pipets. In Activity 1, create a 1.5% hydrogen peroxide solution. Then, label test tubes with catalase concentrations and create catalase dilutions in the test tubes. Next, soak a disk in a catalase dilution and add the disk to the hydrogen peroxide solution. Record the time for the disk to float. Repeat the disk-floating process for a total of 2 trials for each catalase concentration. Then, calculate the average float time for each reaction, determine the distance traveled by floating disks, calculate the rate of each reaction, and graph rate versus percent concentration of enzyme.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for Activity 2 of this investigation. Create a new 100% catalase solution and new 1.5% hydrogen peroxide solution. Then, add 100% catalase solution to each test tube. Next, measure the room temperature and label the test tubes with a temperature series. Then, soak a disk in room temperature catalase, add it to the hydrogen peroxide solution, and record the time for the disk to float. Next, cool a catalase solution and the hydrogen peroxide solution. Then, soak a disk in the cooled catalase, add it to the hydrogen peroxide solution, and record the time for the disk to float. Next, warm a catalase solution and the hydrogen peroxide solution. Then, soak a disk in the warmed catalase, add it to the hydrogen peroxide solution, and record the time for the disk to float. Repeat the disk-floating process with warmed catalase for 3 trials above room temperature. Finally, calculate the rate of each reaction and graph rate versus temperature.
pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for Activity 2 of this investigation. Create a new 100% catalase solution and new 1.5% hydrogen peroxide solution. Then, add 100% catalase solution to each test tube. Next, measure the room temperature and label the test tubes with a temperature series. Then, soak a disk in room temperature catalase, add it to the hydrogen peroxide solution, and record the time for the disk to float. Next, cool a catalase solution and the hydrogen peroxide solution. Then, soak a disk in the cooled catalase, add it to the hydrogen peroxide solution, and record the time for the disk to float. Next, warm a catalase solution and the hydrogen peroxide solution. Then, soak a disk in the warmed catalase, add it to the hydrogen peroxide solution, and record the time for the disk to float. Repeat the disk-floating process with warmed catalase for 3 trials above room temperature. Finally, calculate the rate of each reaction and graph rate versus temperature.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Procedure sections.

Use caution with 3% hydrogen peroxide: It is a strong oxidizer. Use near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eye wash or safety shower if any hydrogen peroxide comes in contact with skin or eyes.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: Hydrogen peroxide will bleach colored fabrics. If spilled on clothing, immediately rinse with water. All wastes from this activity are safe to wash down the drain.

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

options.text: It decreases the activation energy of a reaction.
It increases the pH of the reaction environment.
It changes the shape of a catalyst.
It slows the breakdown of reactants.

It is the energy needed to switch substrates.

assestmentData.question: Catalase is a common enzyme found in animals as well as many plants and microorganisms.  What is the main function of catalase?

options.text: to increase the activation energy for a reaction
to digest food particles in the small intestine
to produce water as it synthesizes DNA

options.text: It changes the shape of the active site.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the Procedure.
Using the single-hole punch, punch out 20 disks from a piece of filter paper into the open Petri dish. If you do not have a hole punch, cut the filter paper into small squares (6–7 mm).
Obtain materials and place them on a counter covered by a plastic trash bag or an old towel to prevent the hydrogen peroxide from discoloring the counter surface.
Turn on a hot water tap and monitor the temperature with the thermometer until a temperature of 35 °C is achieved. Collect approximately 250 mL of the 35 °C water in the beaker.
Measure a level teaspoon of dry yeast, add it to the 35 °C water, and stir thoroughly with the teaspoon. Consider this the 100% catalase solution to be used for the remainder of the lab.
Using the grease pencil, write “100% catalase” on one of the medicine cups.
Pour the yeast suspension into the medicine cup up to the 20.0-mL mark.
Label the bulb of one pipet “water” and the other pipet “catalase” with the grease pencil.

In Activity 1, you will examine the effect of <button class='glossary-text'>enzyme</button> concentration on catalase activity by varying the concentration of catalase on a filter paper disc and measuring the time it takes for the disc to float through a hydrogen peroxide solution as oxygen bubbles form on its surface.
Using the grease pencil, label the empty medicine cup “1.5% H<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>.”

Measure 10 mL of 3% hydrogen peroxide using the 25-mL graduated cylinder and add it to the “1.5% H<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>” medicine cup. Also add 10 mL of room-temperature bottled water to the medicine cup to yield 20 mL of 1.5% hydrogen peroxide. This will be the reaction vessel.
Using the grease pencil, label five test tubes with 0%, 25%, 50%, 75%, and 100%. These labels represent the concentrations of catalase that will be used in each tube.

Use the rule of thumb that 20 drops from a dropper pipet equals 1 mL. Take the pipet labeled “catalase” and add the following drops of catalase to each test tube except for the control, as shown below in the table. Take the pipet labeled “water” and add enough drops of bottled water to obtain a final volume of 20 drops (1 mL) per test tube as shown below in the table.
Note: Always stir the 100% catalase in the medicine cup before removing an aliquot to ensure the catalase is evenly suspended.
Swirl each of the five test tubes to mix the contents.
Note: In steps 6–9, swirl each test tube again prior to dipping the filter paper.

With a pair of forceps, take a dry filter disk out of the Petri dish and dip it into the 0% test tube solution. Tilt the test tube to allow the liquid to run down to the disk. Remove the disk and blot by dragging it across the top of the test tube on both sides.

Start the timer as soon as the disk is placed with forceps on the bottom of the medicine cup containing 20 mL 1.5% hydrogen peroxide. Time in seconds how long it takes the disk to rise to the surface of the peroxide. This is the control data point. Stop timing after 3 minutes if there is no activity. Record the time (in seconds) in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Remove the used disk. Perform an additional trial with a new soaked disk from the control, 0% catalase.

Conduct two trials for each of the remaining catalase solutions (25%, 50%, 75%, and 100%). Swirl each test tube to mix the solution before wetting the disk. If the two trials vary by more than 4 seconds, run a third trial and average the two closest times in seconds. Start with the lowest percent concentration of catalase (25%) and move to each higher concentration. Record the time in seconds in Data Table 1.
For each concentration, average the two times for floating the disks. Always remove the floating disk with forceps before starting the next trial.

Measure the height of the 1.5% hydrogen peroxide solution to the nearest 0.1 cm. This is the distance traveled by the disk from the bottom to the surface of the peroxide, and it will be the same for all trials where the disk floated.

The rate of each reaction can be calculated by the expression R = d/t, where d equals the distance in centimeters (cm) that the disk travels from the bottom of the container to the surface, and t equals average time in second(s). The unit for the rate is cm/s. If the disk remains on the bottom of the container after 3 minutes, the distance traveled (d) will be zero, and the rate will be zero.

Plot a graph for each data point with rate on the y-axis and percent concentration of <button class='glossary-text'>enzyme</button> on the x-axis. If the points are linear, draw a “best-fit” straight line through or near all of the data points. Alternatively, use a computerized spreadsheet with graphing and select “best fit” line.

If Activity 2 will be performed immediately, keep the 1.5% hydrogen peroxide and 100% catalase in their respective medicine cups and ignore preparation steps 1 and 2 in Activity 2. If Activity 2 will be performed at a later time, empty both medicine cups in a sink and rinse with water. All five test tubes should be thoroughly washed and dried. It is safe to empty and rinse the test tubes down the sink drain.

In Activity 2, you will examine the effect of temperature on catalase activity by varying the temperature of catalase and measuring the time it takes for the disc to float through a hydrogen peroxide solution of the same temperature.

If more than an hour has passed since completing Activity 1, prepare a fresh solution of 1.5% hydrogen peroxide by adding 10 mL water to 10 mL 3% hydrogen peroxide in the same medicine cup labeled 1.5% H<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>.

If more than an hour has passed since completing Activity 1, prepare another batch of 100% yeast solution (one teaspoon per cup of warm, 35 °C water, and mix thoroughly. Pour into the medicine cup labeled 100% catalase up to the 20.0-mL mark.
Using the grease pencil, re-label the five test tubes, place them in the test tube rack, and add 20 drops of the 100% catalase with the designated pipet into each test tube.
Measure the room temperature in °C and record the value in Data Table 2 and on one of the 5 test tubes.

Record the temperature that will be 10 °C below room temperature on the second tube. On the third, record 10 °C above room temperature, and on the others 20 °C and 30 °C above room temperature. For example, if temperature is 25 °C, then the tubes would be labeled 15 °C, 25 °C, 35 °C, 45 °C, and 55 °C. Fill in the actual temperatures in Data Table 2

Soak a filter disk in room temperature catalase, blot, and place it using the forceps at the bottom of the 1.5% H2O2 cup. Time how long it takes for the disk to rise to the surface, and record the value in Data Table 2.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: For the below room temperature, set up an ice bath by adding an inch of crushed ice to the beaker.
Place the medicine cup containing 1.5% hydrogen peroxide in the center of the ice and insert the catalase test tube labeled 10 °C below in the ice beside the cup.

Monitor the temperature of the medicine cup by placing the thermometer in the peroxide solution. Remove the cup when the temperature decreases to 10 °C below room temperature. The assumption is made that the temperature of the catalase in the test tube is at the same temperature.
Soak a filter disk in the cooled catalase, blot it on the test tube mouth, and place it on the bottom of the medicine cup. Record how long it takes the disk to rise to the surface.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Discard the ice.

For temperatures above room temperature, set up a water bath by adding hot tap water to the beaker. Insert a thermometer into the water bath to track the temperature. Adjust the temperature by replacing some of the hot water with cooler tap water until the desired temperature is achieved. The total volume of water in the beaker should be approximately 50 mL.

Place the medicine cup of hydrogen peroxide in the center of the beaker. Place the catalase tube labeled 10 °C above room temperature in the beaker beside the medicine cup. Let it stand 2 minutes to allow the temperature in the medicine cup to equilibrate with the water bath.
Soak a filter disk in the warm catalase, blot it, and place on the bottom of the medicine cup. Record how long it takes the disk to rise to the surface.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Repeat steps 12–14 for 20 and 30 °C above room temperature and record the times and temperatures in Data Table 2.
Calculate the rate (d/t) for each temperature and record the values in Data Table 2.
Plot a graph for each data point with rate on the y-axis and temperature on the x-axis.

text: Dispose of solutions down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solutions.
Wipe up any hydrogen peroxide spills, as they could bleach colored fabrics, counter tops, and clothing.
Rinse and dry the lab equipment and return the materials to your equipment kit.
Sanitize the workspace.

Before starting any activities, prepare the filter paper disks, cover your work surface, create a 100% catalase solution, and label your pipets. In Activity 1, create a 1.5% hydrogen peroxide solution. Then, label test tubes with catalase concentrations and create catalase dilutions in the test tubes. Next, soak a disk in a catalase dilution and add the disk to the hydrogen peroxide solution. Record the time for the disk to float. Repeat the disk-floating process for a total of 2 trials for each catalase concentration. Then, calculate the average float time for each reaction, determine the distance traveled by floating disks, calculate the rate of each reaction, and graph rate versus percent concentration of enzyme.

A map describing the procedural workflow for Activity 2 of this investigation. Create a new 100% catalase solution and new 1.5% hydrogen peroxide solution. Then, add 100% catalase solution to each test tube. Next, measure the room temperature and label the test tubes with a temperature series. Then, soak a disk in room temperature catalase, add it to the hydrogen peroxide solution, and record the time for the disk to float. Next, cool a catalase solution and the hydrogen peroxide solution. Then, soak a disk in the cooled catalase, add it to the hydrogen peroxide solution, and record the time for the disk to float. Next, warm a catalase solution and the hydrogen peroxide solution. Then, soak a disk in the warmed catalase, add it to the hydrogen peroxide solution, and record the time for the disk to float. Repeat the disk-floating process with warmed catalase for 3 trials above room temperature. Finally, calculate the rate of each reaction and graph rate versus temperature.

data.title: Activation energy
data.content: The minimum amount of energy required to start a chemical reaction

data.title: Conformational change
data.content: The alteration of the shape of a molecule

data.title: Denaturing
data.content: Destroying the characteristic properties of a biological macromolecule (such as a protein) by heat, acidity, or other environmental condition

data.title: Enzyme
data.content: A specialized protein that acts as catalysts to speed up chemical reactions by lowering the activation energy required for the reaction

data.title: Substrate
data.content: The substance on which an enzyme acts
